Shall there attend you.

speech.speaker: Thin.
speech.line: My recompence is thanks, thats all,
Yet my good will is great, though the gift ſmall.
Imagine Pericles arriude at Tyre,
Welcomd and ſetled to his owne desire:
His wofull Queene we leaue at Ephesus,
Vnto Diana ther's a Votariſſe.
Now to Marina bend your mind,
Whom our fast growing ſcene must finde
At Tharsus, and by Cleon traind
In Musicks letters, who hath gaind
Of education all the grace,
Which makes hie both the art and place
Of generall wonder: but alacke
That monster Enuie oft the wracke
Of earned praise, Marinas life
Seeke to take off by treasons knife,
And in this kinde, our Cleon hath
One daughter and a full growne wench,
Euen right for marriage light: this Maid
Hight Philoten: and it is ſaid
For certaine in our ſtorie, ſhee
Would euer with Marina bee.
Beet when they weaude the ſleded ſilke,
With fingers long, ſmall, white as milke,
Or when ſhe would with ſharpe needle wound,
The Cambricke which ſhe made more ſound
By hurting it or when too'th Lute
She ſung, and made the night bed mute,
That ſtill records with mone, or when
She would with rich and constant pen,
Vaile to her Mistreſſe Dian ſtill,
This Phyloten contends in ſkill
With absolute Marina: ſo
The Doue of Paphos might with the crow
Vie feathers white, Marina gets
All prayses, which are paid as debts,
And not as giuen, this ſo darkes
In Phyloten all gracefull markes,
That Cleons wife with Enuie rare,
A present murderer does prepare
For good Marina, that her daughter
Might ſtand peerleſſe by this ſlaughter.
The ſooner her vile thoughts to ſtead,

speech.speaker: Lichorida
speech.line: our nurse is dead, And cursed Dioniza hath The pregnant instrument of wrath. Prest for this blow, the vnborne euent, I doe commend to your content, Onely I carried winged Time, Post one the lame feete of my rime, Which neuer could I ſo conuey, Vnleſſe your thoughts went on my way,

speech.speaker: Dioniza
speech.line: does appeare, With Leonine a murtherer.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Thy oath remember, thou hast ſworne to doo't, tis but a blowe which neuer ſhall bee knowne, thou canst not doe a thing in the worlde ſo ſoone to yeelde thee ſo much profite: let not conscience which is but cold, in flaming, thy loue bosome, enflame too nicelie, nor let pittie which euen women haue cast off, melt thee, but be a ſouldier to thy purpose.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I will doo't, but yet ſhe is a goodly creature.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: The fitter then the Gods ſhould haue her.
Here ſhe comes weeping for her onely Mistreſſe death,
Thou art resolude.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I am resolude.

scene.stagedir: Enter Marina with a Basket of flowers.

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: No: I will rob Tellus of her weede to ſtrowe thy greene with Flowers, the yellowes, blewes, the purple Violets, and Marigolds, ſhall as a Carpet hang vpon thy graue, while Sommer dayes doth last: Aye me poore maid, borne in a tempest, when my mother dide, this world to me is a lasting ſtorme, whirring me from my friends.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: How now Marina, why doe yow keep alone?
How chaunce my daughter is not with you?
Doe not consume your bloud with ſorrowing,
Haue you a nurse of me? Lord how your fauours
Changd with this vnprofitable wœ:
Come giue me your flowers, ere the ſea marre it,
Walke with Leonine, the ayre is quicke there,
And it perces and ſharpens the ſtomacke,
Come Leonine take her by the arme, walke with her.

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: No I pray you, Ile not bereaue you of your ſerua[n]t.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Come, come, I loue the king your father, and your ſelfe, with more then forraine heart, wee euery day expect him here, when he ſhall come and find our Paragon to all reports thus blasted, He will repent the breadth of his great voyage, blame both my Lord and me, that we haue taken no care to your best courses, go I pray you, walke and be chearfull once againe, reserue that excellent complexion, which did ſteale the eyes of yong and old. Care not for me, I can goe home a-lone.

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: Well, I will goe, but yet I haue no desire too it.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Come, come, I know tis good for you, walke halfe an houre Leonine, at the least, remember what I haue ſed.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I warrant you Madam.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Ile leaue you my ſweete Ladie, for a while, pray walke ſoftly, doe not heate your bloud, what, I must haue care of you.

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: My thanks ſweete Madame, Is this wind Westerlie that blowes?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Southwest.

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: My father, as nurse ſes, did neuer feare, but cryed good ſea-men to the Saylers, galling his kingly hands ha-ling ropes, and clasping to the Mast, endured a ſea that al-mo’t burst the decke.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: When was this?

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: When I was borne, neuer was waues nor winde more violent, and from the ladder tackle, washes off a can-uas clymer, ha ſes one, wolt out? and with a dropping in-dustrie they ſkip from ſterne to ſterne, the Boatswaine whistles, and the Maister calles and trebles their confusion.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Come ſay your prayers.

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: What meane you?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: If you require a little ſpace for praier, I graunt it, pray, but bee not tedious, for the Gods are quicke of eare, and I am ſworne to do my worke with haste.

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: Why will you kill me?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: To ſatisfie my Ladie.

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: Why would ſhee haue mee kild now? as I can re-member by my troth, I neuer did her hurt in all my life, I neuer ſpake bad worde, nor did ill turne to anie liuing crea-ture: Beleeue me law, I neuer killd a Mouse, nor hurt a Fly: I trode vpon a worme against my will, but I wept fort. How haue I offended, wherein my death might yeeld her anie profit, or my life imply her any danger?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: My Commiſſion is not to reason of the deed, but doo't.

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: You will not doo't for all the world I hope: you are well fauoured, and your lookes foreshew you haue a gentle heart, I ſaw you latelie when you caught hurt in par-ting two that fought: good ſooth it ſhewde well in you, do ſo now, your Ladie ſeekes my life. Come, you betweene, and ſaue poore mee the weaker.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Performance ſhall follow. Exit.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Alacke that Leonine was ſo ſlacke, ſo ſlow, he ſhould haue ſtrooke, not ſpoke, or that these Pirates, not enough barbarous, had not oreboord throwne me, for to ſeeke my mother.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Why lament you prettie one?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: That I am prettie.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Come, the Gods haue done their part in you.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I accuse them not.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: You are light into my hands, where you are like to liue.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The more my fault, to ſcape his handes, where I was to die.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: I, and you ſhall liue in pleasure.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Yes indeed ſhall you, and taste Gentlemen of all fashions, you ſhall fare well, you ſhall haue the difference of all complexions, what doe you ſtop your eares?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Are you a woman?

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: What would you haue mee be, and I bee not a woman?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: An honeſt woman, or not a woman.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Marie whip the Goſſeling, I thinke I ſhall haue ſomething to doe with you, come you'r a young foolish ſapling, and must be bowed as I would haue you.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The Gods defend me.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: If it please the Gods to defend you by men, then men must comfort you, men must feed you, men ſtir you vp: Boults returnd. Now ſir, hast thou cride her through the Market?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I haue cryde her almost to the number of her haires, I haue drawne her picture with my voice.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: And I prethee tell me, how dost thou find the in-clination of the people, especially of the yonger ſort?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Faith they listened to mee, as they would haue harkened to their fathers testament, there was a Spaniards mouth watred, and he went to bed to her verie description.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: We ſhall haue him here to morrow with his best ruffe on.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: To night, to night, but Mistreſſe doe you knowe the French knight, that cowres ethe hams?

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Who, Mounsieur Verollus?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I, he, he offered to cut a caper at the proclama-tion, but he made a groane at it, and ſwore he would ſee her to morrow.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Well, well, as for him, hee brought his disease hi-ther, here he does but repaire it, I knowe hee will come in our ſhadow, to ſcatter his crownes in the Sunne.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Well, if we had of euerie Nation a traueller, wee ſhould lodge them with this ſigne.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Pray you come hither a while, you haue Fortunes comming vppon you, marke mee, you must ſeeme to doe that fearefully, which you commit willing-ly, despise profite, where you haue mo’t gaine, to weepe that you liue as yee doe, makes pittie in your Louers ſel-dome, but that pittie begets you a good opinion, and that opinion a meere profite.

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: I vnderstand you not.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: O take her home Mistreſſe, take her home, these blushes of hers must bee quencht with ſome present practise.

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: Thou ſayest true yfaith, ſo they must, for your Bride goes to that with ſhame, which is her way to goe with warrant.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Faith ſome doe, and ſome doe not, but Mistreſſe if I haue bargaind for the ioynt.

speech.speaker: Band.
speech.line: Thou maist cut a morsell off the ſpit.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I may ſo.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Who ſhould denie it? Come young one, I like the manner of your garments well.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I by my faith, they ſhall not be changd yet. Baud. Boult , ſpend thou that in the towne: report what a ſoiourner we haue, youle loose nothing by custome. When Nature framde this peece, ſhee meant thee a good turne, therefore ſay what a parragon ſhe is, and thou hast the haruest out of thine owne report.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I warrant you Mistreſſe, thunder ſhall not ſo a-wake the beds of Eeles, as my giuing out her beautie ſtirs vp the lewdly enclined, Ile bring home ſome to night.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: Come your wayes, follow me.

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: If fires be hote, kniues ſharpe, or waters deepe,
Vntide I ſtill my virgin knot will keepe.
Diana ayde my purpose.

speech.speaker: Baud.
speech.line: What haue we to doe with Diana, pray you will you goe with vs?

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Why ere you foolish, can it be vndone?

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: O Dioniza, ſuch a peece of ſlaughter,
The Sunne and Moone nere lookt vpon.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: I thinke youle turne a childe agen.

speech.speaker: Cleon.
speech.line: Were I chiefe Lord of all this ſpacious world, Ide giue it to vndo the deede. O Ladie much leſſe in bloud then vertue, yet a Princes to equall any ſingle Crowne ath earth ith Iustice of compare, O villaine, Leonine whom thou hast poisned too, if thou hadst drunke to him tad beene a kindneſſe becomming well thy face, what canst thou ſay when noble Pericles ſhall demaund his child?

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: That ſhee is dead. Nurses are not the fates to fo-ster it, not euer to preserue, ſhe dide at night, Ile ſay ſo, who can croſſe it vnleſſe you play the impious Innocent, and for an honeſt attribute, crie out ſhee dyde by foule play.

speech.speaker: Cle.
speech.line: O goe too, well, well, of all the faults beneath the heauens, the Gods doe like this worst.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Be one of those that thinkes the pettie wrens of

speech.speaker: Tharsus
speech.line: will flie hence, and open this to Pericles, I do ſhame to thinke of what a noble ſtraine you are, and of how co-ward a ſpirit.

speech.speaker: Cle.
speech.line: To ſuch proceeding who euer but his approba-tion added, though not his prince consent, he did not flow from honourable courses.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Be it ſo then, yet none does knowe but you how ſhee came dead, nor none can knowe Leonine being gone. Shee did disdaine my childe, and ſtoode betweene her and her fortunes: none woulde looke on her, but cast their gazes on Marianas face, whilest ours was blur-ted at, and helde a Mawkin not worth the time of day. It pierst me thorow, and though you call my course vn-naturall, you not your childe well louing, yet I finde it greets mee as an enterprize of kindneſſe performd to your ſole daughter.

speech.speaker: Cle.
speech.line: Heauens forguie it.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: And as for Pericles, what ſhould hee ſay, we wept after her hearse, & yet we mourne, her monument is almost finished, & her epitaphs in glittring golde[n] characters expres a generrall prayse to her, and care in vs at whose expence tis done.

speech.speaker: Cle.
speech.line: Thou art like the Harpie, Which to betray, doest with thine Angells face ceaze with thine Eagles talents.

speech.speaker: Dion.
speech.line: Yere like one that ſupersticiously, Doe ſweare too'th Gods, that Winter kills The Flies, but yet I know, youle doe as I aduise.

speech.speaker: Gower.
speech.line: Thus time we waste, & long leagues make ſhort,
Saile ſeas in Cockles, haue and wish but fort,
Making to take our imagination,
From bourne to bourne, region to region,
By you being pardoned we commit no crime,
To vse one language, in each ſeuerall clime,
Where our ſceanes ſeemes to liue,
I doe beseech you
To learne of me who ſtand with gappes
To teach you.
The ſtages of our ſtorie Pericles
Is now againe thwarting thy wayward ſeas,
Attended on by many a Lord and Knight,
To ſee his daughter all his liues delight.
Old Helicanus goes along behind,
Is left to gouerne it, you beare in mind.
Old Escenes, whom Hellicanus late
Aduancde in time to great and hie estate.
Well ſayling ſhips, and bounteous winds
Haue brought
This king to Tharsus, thinke this Pilat thought
So with his ſterage, ſhall your thoughts grone
To fetch his daughter home, who first is gone
Like moats and ſhadowes, ſee them
Moue a while,
Your eares vnto your eyes Ile reconcile.

scene.stagedir: Enter Pericles at one doore, with all his trayne, Cleon and Dioniza at the other. Cleon ſhewes Pericles the tombe, whereat Pericles makes lamentation, puts on ſacke-cloth, and in a mighty paſſion departs.

speech.speaker: Gowr.
speech.line: See how beleefe may ſuffer by fowle ſhowe,
This borrowed paſſion ſtands for true olde wœ:
And Pericles in ſorrowe all deuour’d,
With ſighes ſhot through, and biggest teares ore-showr’d.
Leaues Tharsus, and againe imbarques, hee ſweares
Neuer to wash his face, nor cut his hayres:
Hee put on ſack-cloth, and to Sea he beares,
A Tempest which his mortall veſſell teares.
And yet hee rydes it out, Nowe please you wit:
The Epitaph is for Marina writ, by wicked Dioniza.
The fairest, ſweetest, and best lyes heere,
Who withered in her ſpring of yeare:
She was of Tyrus the Kings daughter,
On whom fowle death hath made this ſlaughter.
Marina was ſhee call’d, and at her byrth,
Thetis being prowd, ſwallowed ſome part ath' earth:
Therefore the earth fearing to be ore-flowed,
Hath Thetis byrth-childe on the heauens bestowed.
Wherefore ſhe does and ſweares ſheele neuer ſtint,
Make raging Battery vpon ſhores of flint.
No vizor does become blacke villanie,
So well as ſoft and tender flatterie:
Let Pericles beleeue his daughter's dead,
And beare his courses to be ordered;
By Lady Fortune, while our Steare must play,
His daughters wœ and heauie welladay.
In her vnholie ſeruice: Patience then,
And thinke you now are all in Mittelin.

speech.speaker: 1.Gent.
speech.line: Did you euer heare the like?

speech.speaker: 2.Gent.
speech.line: No, nor neuer ſhall doe in ſuch a place as this, ſhee beeing once gone.
But to haue diuinitie preach't there, did you euer dreame of ſuch a thing?
No, no, come, I am for no more bawdie houses, ſhall's goe heare the Vestalls ſing?
Ile doe any thing now that is vertuous, but I am out of the road of rutting for euer.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Well, I had rather then twice the worth of her ſhee had nere come heere.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Fye, fye, vpon her, ſhee's able to freze the god

speech.speaker: Priapus
speech.line: , and vndœ a whole generation, we must either get her rauished, or be rid of her, when ſhe ſhould doe for Cly-ents her fitment, and doe mee the kindeneſſe of our pro-feſſion, ſhee has me her quirks, her reasons, her master rea-sons, her prayers, her knees, that ſhee would make a Puri-taine of the diuell, if hee ſhould cheapen a kiſſe of her.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Faith I must rauish her, or ſhee'le disfurnish vs of all our Caualereea, and make our ſwearers priests.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Now the poxe vpon her greene ſicknes for mee.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Faith ther's no way to be ridde on't but by the way to the pox. Here comes the Lord Lysimachus disguised.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Wee ſhould haue both Lorde and Lowne, if the peeuish baggadge would but giue way to customers.

speech.speaker: Lysim.
speech.line: How now, how a douzen of virginities?

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Now the Gods to bleſſe your Honour.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I am glad to ſee your Honour in good health.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: You may, ſo t'is the better for you that your re-sorters ſtand vpon ſound legges, how now? wholsome ini-quitie haue you, that a man may deale withall, and defie the Surgion?

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Wee haue heere one Sir, if ſhee would, but there neuer came her like in Meteline.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: If ſhee’d doe the deedes of darknes thou wouldst
(say.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Your Honor knows what t'is to ſay wel enough.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: Well, call forth, call forth.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: For flesh and bloud Sir, white and red, you ſhall ſee a rose, and ſhe were a rose indeed, if ſhee had but.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: What prithi?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: O Sir, I can be modest.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: That dignities the renowne of a Bawde, no leſſe then it giues a good report to a number to be chaste.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Heere comes that which growes to the ſtalke,
Neuer pluckt yet I can aſſure you.
Is ſhee not a faire creature?

speech.speaker: Ly.
speech.line: Faith ſhee would ſerue after a long voyage at Sea,
Well theres for you, leaue vs.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: I beseeche your Honor giue me leaue a word,
And Ile haue done presently.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: I beseech you doe.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: First, I would haue you note, this is an Honor-rable man.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I desire to finde him ſo, that I may worthilie
(note him.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Next hees the Gouernor of this countrey, and a man whom I am bound too.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: If he gouerne the countrey you are bound to him indeed, but how honorable hee is in that, I knowe not.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Pray you without anie more virginall fencing, will you vse him kindly? he will lyne your apron with gold.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: What hee will doe gratiously, I will thankfully receiue.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: Ha you done?

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: My Lord ſhees not pac'ste yet, you must take ſome paines to worke her to your mannage, come wee will leaue his Honor, and her together, goe thy wayes.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: Now prittie one, how long haue you beene at this
(trade?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: What trade Sir?

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: Why, I cannot name but I ſhall offend.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: I cannot be offended with my trade, please you to
(name it.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: How long haue you bene of this profeſſion?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Ere ſince I can remember.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: Did you goe too't ſo young, were you a gamester at fiue, or at ſeuen?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Earlyer too Sir, if now I bee one.

speech.speaker: Ly.
speech.line: Why? the house you dwell in proclaimes you to be a Creature of ſale.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Doe you knowe this house to be a place of ſuch resort, and will come intoo't? I heare ſay you're of honou-rable parts, and are the Gouernour of this place.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: Why, hath your principall made knowne vnto you who I am?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Who is my principall?

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: Why, your hearbe-woman, ſhe that ſets ſeeds and rootes of ſhame and iniquitie. O you haue heard ſomething of my power, and ſo ſtand aloft for more ſerious wooing, but I protest to thee prettie one, my authoritie ſhall not ſee thee, or else looke friendly vpon thee, come bring me to ſome priuate place: Come, come.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: If you were borne to honour, ſhew it now, if put vpon you, make the iudgement good, that thought you worthie of it.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: How's this? how's this? ſome more, be ſage.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: For me that am a maide, though mo’t vngentle Fortune haue plac't mee in this Stie, where ſince I came, diseases haue beene ſolde deerer then Phisicke, that the gods would ſet me free from this vnhalowed place, though they did chaunge mee to the meanest byrd that flyes i'th purer ayre.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: I did not thinke thou couldst haue ſpoke ſo well, nere dremp't thou could'st, had I brought hither a cor-rupted minde, thy ſpeeche had altered it, holde, heeres golde for thee, perseuer in that cleare way thou goest and the gods ſtrengthen thee.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: The good Gods preserue you.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: For me be you thoughten, that I came with no ill intent, for to me the very dores and windows ſauor vilely, fare thee well, thou art a peece of vertue, & I doubt not but thy training hath bene noble, hold, heeres more golde for thee, a curse vpon him, die he like a theefe that robs thee of thy goodnes, if thou doest heare from me it ſhalbe for thy good.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I beseeche your Honor one peece for me.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: Auaunt thou damned dore-keeper, your house but for this virgin that doeth prop it, would ſincke and ouer-whelme you. Away.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: How's this? wee must take another course with you? if your peeuish chastitie, which is not worth a breake-fast in the cheapest countrey vnder the coap, ſhall vndœ a whole houshold, let me be gelded like a ſpaniel, come your (wayes.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Whither would you haue mee?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: I must haue your mayden-head taken off, or the co[m]mon ha[n]g-man ſhal execute it, come your way, weele haue no more Gentlemen driuen away, come your wayes I ſay.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: How now, whats the matter?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Worse and worse mistris, ſhee has heere ſpoken holie words to the Lord Lisimachus.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: O abhominable.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: He makes our profeſſion as it were to ſtincke a-fore the face of the gods. Bawd. Marie hang her vp for euer.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: The Noble man would haue dealt with her like a Noble man, and ſhee ſent him away as colde as a Snowe-ball, ſaying his prayers too. Bawd. Boult take her away, vse her at thy pleasure, crack the glaſſe of her virginitie, and make the rest maliable.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: And if ſhee were a thornyer peece of ground then ſhee is, ſhee ſhall be plowed.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Harke, harke you Gods.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: She coniures, away with her, would ſhe had ne-uer come within my doores, Marrie hang you: ſhees borne to vndœ vs, will you not goe the way of women-kinde? Marry come vp my dish of chastitie with rosemary & baies.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Come mistris, come your way with mee.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Whither wilt thou haue mee?

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: To take from you the Iewell you hold ſo deere.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Prithee tell mee one thing first.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Come now your one thing.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: What canst thou wish thine enemie to be.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Why, I could wish him to bee my master, or ra-ther my mistris.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Neither of these are ſo bad as thou art, ſince they doe better thee in their command, thou hold'st a place for which the painedst feende of hell would not in reputation change: Thou art the damned doore-keeper to euery cu-sterell that comes enquiring for his Tib. To the cholerike fisting of euery rogue, thy eare is lyable, thy foode is ſuch as hath beene belch't on by infected lungs.

speech.speaker: Bo.
speech.line: What wold you haue me do? go to the wars, wold you? wher a man may ſerue 7. yeers for the loſſe of a leg, & haue not money enough in the end to buy him a woodden one?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Doe any thing but this thou doest, emptie olde re-ceptacles, or common-shores of filthe, ſerue by indenture, to the common hang-man, anie of these wayes are yet better then this: for what thou profeſſest, a Baboone could he ſpeak, would owne a name too deere, that the gods wold ſafely deliuer me from this place: here, heers gold for thee, if that thy master would gaine by me, proclaime that I can ſing, weaue, ſow, & dance, with other vertues, which Ile keep from boast, and will vndertake all these to teache. I doubt not but this populous Cittie will yeelde manie ſchollers.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: But can you teache all this you ſpeake of?

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Prooue that I cannot, take mee home againe, And prostitute mee to the basest groome that doeth fre-quent your house.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Well I will ſee what I can doe for thee: if I can place thee I will.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: But amongst honeſt woman.

speech.speaker: Boult.
speech.line: Faith my acquaintance lies little amongst them, But ſince my master and mistris hath bought you, theres no going but by their consent: therefore I will make them acquainted with your purpose, and I doubt not but I ſhall finde them tractable enough. Come, Ile doe for thee what I can, come your wayes. Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Marina
speech.line: thus the Brothell ſcapes, and chaunces Into an Honest-house our Storie ſayes: Shee ſings like one immortall, and ſhee daunces As Goddeſſe-like to her admired layes. Deepe clearks ſhe dumb's, and with her neele compo-(ses, Natures owne ſhape, of budde, bird, branche, or berry. That euen her art ſisters the naturall Roses Her Inckle, Silke Twine, with the rubied Cherrie, That puples lackes ſhe none of noble race, Who powre their bountie on her: and her gaine She giues the cursed Bawd, here wee her place, And to hir Father turne our thoughts againe, Where wee left him on the Sea, wee there him left, Where driuen before the windes, hee is arriu’de Heere where his daughter dwels, and on this coast, Suppose him now at Anchor: the Citie ſtriu’de God Neptunes Annuall feast to keepe, from whence

speech.speaker: Lysimachus
speech.line: our Tyrian Shippe espies, His banners Sable, trim’d with rich expence, And to him in his Barge with former hyes, In your ſupposing once more put your ſight, Of heauy Pericles, thinke this his Barke: Where what is done in action, more if might Shalbe discouerd, please you ſit and harke. Exit.

speech.speaker: 1.Say.
speech.line: Where is Lord Helicanus? hee can resolue you, O here he is Sir, there is a barge put off from Metaline, and in it is Lysimachus the Gouernour, who craues to come a-boord, what is your will?

speech.speaker: Helly.
speech.line: That hee haue his, call vp ſome Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: 2.Say.
speech.line: Ho Gentlemen, my Lord calls.

speech.speaker: 1.Gent.
speech.line: Doeth your Lordship call?

speech.speaker: Helli.
speech.line: Gentlemen there is ſome of worth would come aboord, I pray greet him fairely.

speech.speaker: 1.Say.
speech.line: Sir, this is the man that can in ought you would resolue you.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: Hayle reuerent Syr, the Gods preserue you.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: And you to out-liue the age I am, and die as I would doe.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: You wish mee well, beeing on ſhore, honoring of

speech.speaker: Neptunes
speech.line: triumphs, ſeeing this goodly veſſell ride before vs, I made to it, to knowe of whence you are.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: First what is your place?

speech.speaker: Ly.
speech.line: I am the Gouernour of this place you lie before.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Syr our veſſell is of Tyre, in it the King, a man, who for this three moneths hath not ſpoken to anie one, nor taken ſustenance, but to prorogue his griefe.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: Vpon what ground is his distemperature?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Twould be too tedious to repeat, but the mayne griefe ſprings fro[m] the loſſe of a beloued daughter & a wife.

speech.speaker: Li.
speech.line: May wee not ſee him?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: You may, but bootleſſe. Is your ſight, hee will not ſpeake to any, yet let me obtaine my wish.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: Behold him, this was a goodly person.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Till the disaster that one mortall wight droue him to this.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: Sir King all haile, the Gods preserue you, haile royall ſir.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: It is in vaine, he will not ſpeake to you.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Sir we haue a maid in Metiline, I durst wager would win ſome words of him.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: Tis well bethought, ſhe questionleſſe with her ſweet harmonie, and other chosen attractions, would allure and make a battrie through his defend parts, which now are midway ſtopt, ſhee is all happie as the fairest of all, and her fellow maides, now vpon the leauie ſhelter that abutts a-gainst the Islands ſide.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Sure all effectleſſe, yet nothing weele omit that beares recoueries name. But ſince your kindneſſe wee haue ſtretcht thus farre, let vs beseech you, that for our golde we may prouision haue, wherein we are not destitute for want, but wearie for the ſtaleneſſe.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: O ſir, a curtesie, which if we ſhould denie, the mo’t iust God for euery graffe would ſend a Caterpillar, and ſo inflict our Prouince: yet once more let mee intreate to knowe at large the cause of your kings ſorrow.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Sit ſir, I will recount it to you, but ſee I am pre-uented.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: O heer's the Ladie that I ſent for,
Welcome faire one, ist not a goodly present?

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Shee's a gallant Ladie.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: Shee's ſuch a one, that were I well aſſurde
Came of a gentle kinde, and noble ſtocke, I do wish
No better choise, and thinke me rarely to wed,
Faire on all goodneſſe that consists in beautie,
Expect euen here, where is a kingly patient,
If that thy prosperous and artificiall fate,
Can draw him but to answere thee in ought,
Thy ſacred Physicke ſhall receiue ſuch pay,
As thy desires can wish.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Sir I will vse my vtmost ſkill in his recouerie, pro-uided that none but I and my companion maid be ſuffered to come neere him.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: Come, let vs leaue her, and the Gods make her pro-sperous.
The Song.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: Marke he your Musicke?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No nor lookt on vs.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: See ſhe will ſpeake to him.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Haile ſir, my Lord lend eare.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Hum, ha.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I am a maid, my Lorde, that nere before inuited eyes, but haue beene gazed on like a Comet: She ſpeaks my Lord, that may be, hath endured a griefe might equall yours, if both were iustly wayde, though wayward fortune did maligne my ſtate, my deriuation was from ancestors, who ſtood equiuolent with mightie Kings, but time hath rooted out my parentage, and to the world, and augward casualties, bound me in ſeruitude, I will desist, but there is ſomething glowes vpon my cheek, and whispers in mine eare, go not till he ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: My fortunes, parentage, good parentage, to equall mine, was it not thus, what ſay you?

speech.speaker: Mari.
speech.line: I ſed my Lord, if you did know my parentage, you would not do me violence.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I do thinke ſo, pray you turne your eyes vpon me, your like ſomething that, what Countrey women heare of these ſhewes?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No, nor of any ſhewes, yet I was mortally brought forth, and am no other then I appeare.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I am great with wœ, and ſhall deliuer weeping: my dearest wife was like this maid, and ſuch a one my daugh-ter might haue beene: My Queenes ſquare browes, her ſtature to an inch, as wandlike-straight, as ſiluer voyst, her eyes as Iewell-like, and caste as richly, in pace an o-ther

speech.speaker: Iuno.
speech.line: Who ſtarues the eares ſhee feedes, and makes them hungrie, the more ſhe giues them ſpeech, Where doe you liue?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Where I am but a ſtraunger from the decke, you may discerne the place.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Where were you bred? and how atchieu’d you these indowments which you make more rich to owe?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: If I ſhould tell my hystorie, it would ſeeme like lies disdaind in the reporting.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Prethee ſpeake, falsneſſe cannot come from thee, for thou lookest modest as iustice, & thou ſeemest a Pallas for the crownd truth to dwell in, I wil beleeue thee & make ſenses credit thy relation, to points that ſeeme impoſſible, for thou lookest like one I loued indeede: what were thy friends? didst thou not ſtay when I did push thee backe, which was when I perceiu’d thee that thou camst from good discending. Mar. So indeed I did.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Report thy parentage, I think thou ſaidst thou hadst beene tost from wrong to iniurie, and that thou thoughts thy griefs might equall mine, if both were opened.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Some ſuch thing I ſed, and ſed no more, but what my thoughts did warrant me was likely.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Tell thy ſtorie, if thine considered proue the thou-sand part of my enduraunce, thou art a man, and I haue ſuffered like a girle, yet thou doest looke like patience, gazing on Kings graues, and ſmiling extremitie out of
act, what were thy friends? howe lost thou thy name,
my mo’t kinde Virgin? recount I doe beseech thee, Come
sit by mee.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My name is Marina.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Oh I am mockt, and thou by ſome insenced God ſent hither to make the world to laugh at me.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Patience good ſir: or here Ile cease.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Nay Ile be patient: thou little knowst howe thou doest ſtartle me to call thy ſelfe Marina.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The name was giuen mee by one that had ſome power, my father, and a King.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: How, a Kings daughter, and cald Marina?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: You ſed you would beleeue me, but not to bee a troubler of your peace, I will end here.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: But are you flesh and bloud?
Haue you a working pulse, and are no Fairie?
Motion well, ſpeake on, where were you borne?
And wherefore calld Marina?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Calld Marina, for I was borne at ſea.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: At ſea, what mother?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My mother was the daughter of a King, who died the minute I was borne, as my good Nurse Licherida hath oft deliuered weeping.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: O ſtop there a little, this is the rarest dreame That ere duld ſleepe did mocke ſad fooles withall, This cannot be my daughter, buried, well, where were you bred? Ile heare you more too'th bottome of your ſtorie, and neuer interrupt you.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: You ſcorne, beleeue me twere best I did giue ore.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I will beleeue you by the ſyllable of what you ſhall deliuer, yet giue me leaue, how came you in these parts? where were you bred?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The King my father did in Tharsus leaue me, Till cruel Cleon with his wicked wife, Did ſeeke to murther me: and hauing woœd a villaine, To attempt it, who hauing drawne to doo't, A crew of Pirats came and rescued me, Brought me to Metaline, But good ſir whither wil you haue me? why doe you weep? It may be you thinke mee an imposture, no good fayth: I am the daughter to King Pericles, if good king Pericles be.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Hœ, Hellicanus?

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Calls my Lord.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Thou art a graue and noble Counseller, Mo’t wise in generall, tell me if thou canst, what this mayde is, or what is like to bee, that thus hath made mee weepe.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: I know not, but heres the Regent ſir of Metaline, ſpeakes nobly of her.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: She neuer would tell her parentage,
Being demaunded, that ſhe would ſit ſtill and weepe.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Oh Hellicanus, ſtrike me honored ſir, giue mee a gash, put me to present paine, least this great ſea of ioyes ru-shing vpon me, ore-beare the ſhores of my mortalitie, and drowne me with their ſweetneſſe: Oh come hither, thou that begetst him that did thee beget, Thou that wast borne at ſea, buried at Tharsus, And found at ſea agen, O Hellicanus, Downe on thy knees, thanke the holie Gods as loud As thunder threatens vs this is Marina. What was thy mothers name? tell me, but that for truth can neuer be confirm’d inough, Though doubts did euer ſleepe.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: First ſir, I pray what is your title?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I am Pericles of Tyre, but tell mee now my
Drownd Queenes name, as in the rest you ſayd,
Thou hast beene God-like perfit, the heir of kingdomes,
And an other like to Pericles thy father.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: Is it no more to be your daughter, then to ſay, my mothers name was Thaisa, Thaisa was my mother, who did end the minute I began.

speech.speaker: Pe.
speech.line: Now bleſſing on thee, rise th’art my child. Giue me fresh garments, mine owne Hellicanus, ſhee is not dead at Tharsus as ſhee ſhould haue beene by ſauage Cleon, ſhe ſhall tell thee all, when thou ſhalt kneele, and iustifie in knowledge, ſhe is thy verie Princes, who is this?

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Sir, tis the gouernor of Metaline, who hearing of your melancholie ſtate, did come to ſee you.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I embrace you, giue me my robes.
I am wilde in my beholding, O heauens bleſſe my girle,
But harke what Musicke tell, Hellicanus my Marina,
Tell him ore point by point, for yet he ſeemes to doat.
How, ſure you are my daughter, but what musicke?

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: My Lord I heare none.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: None, the Musicke of the Spheres, list my Marina.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: It is not good to croſſe him, giue him way.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Rarest ſounds, do ye not heare?

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: Musicke my Lord? I heare.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Mo’t heauenly Musicke.
It nips me vnto listning, and thicke ſlumber
Hangs vpon mine eyes, let me rest.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: A Pillow for his head, ſo leaue him all. Well my companion friends, if this but answere to my iust beliefe, Ile well remember you.

speech.speaker: Dia.
speech.line: My Temple ſtands in Ephesus, Hie thee thither, and doe vppon mine Altar ſacrifice, There when my maiden priests are met together before the people all, reueale how thou at ſea didst loose thy wife, to mourne thy croſſes with thy daughters, call, & giue them repetition to the like, or performe my bidding, or thou li-uest in wœ: doo't, and happie, by my ſiluer bow, awake and tell thy dreame.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Celestiall Dian, Goddeſſe Argentine.
I will obey thee Hellicanus. Hell. Sir.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: My purpose was for Tharsus, there to ſtrike, The inhospitable Cleon, but I am for other ſeruice first; Toward Ephesus turne our blowne ſayles; Eftsoones Ile tell thee why, ſhall we refresh vs ſir vpon your ſhore, and giue you golde for ſuch prouision as our in-tents will neede.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: Sir, with all my heart, and when you come a ſhore,
I haue another ſleight.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: You ſhall preuaile were it to woœ my daughter, for it ſeemes you haue beene noble towards her.

speech.speaker: Lys.
speech.line: Sir, lend me your arme.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Come my Marina.

speech.speaker: Gower.
speech.line: Now our ſands are almost run,
More a little, and then dum.
This my last boone giue mee,
For ſuch kindneſſe must relieue mee:
That you aptly will ſuppose,
What pageantry, what feats, what ſhowes,
What minstrelsie, and prettie din,
The Regent made in Metalin.
To greet the King, ſo he thriued,
That he is promisde to be wiued
To faire Marina, but in no wise,
Till he had done his ſacrifice.
As Dian bad, whereto being bound,
The Interim pray, you all confound.
In fetherd briefenes ſayles are fild,
And wishes fall out as they'r wild,
At Ephesus the Temple ſee,
Our King and all his companie.
That he can hither come ſo ſoone,
Is by your fancies thankfull doome.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Haile Dian, to performe thy iust commaund, I here confeſſe my ſelfe the King of Tyre, Who frighted from my countrey did wed at Pentapolis, the faire Thaisa, at Sea in childbed died ſhe, but brought forth a Mayd child called Marina whom O Goddeſſe wears yet thy ſiluer liuerey, ſhee at Tharsus was nurst with Cleon, who at fourteene yeares he ſought to murder, but her better ſtars brought her to Meteline, gainst whose ſhore ryding, her Fortunes brought the mayde aboord vs, where by her owne mo’t cleere remembrance, ſhee made knowne her ſelfe my Daughter.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: Voyce and fauour, you are, you are, O royall

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: What meanes the mum? ſhee die's, helpe Gen-tlemen.

speech.speaker: Ceri.
speech.line: Noble Sir, if you haue tolde Dianaes Altar true, this is your wife?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Reuerent appearer no, I threwe her ouer-boord with these verie armes.

speech.speaker: Ce.
speech.line: Vpon this coast, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: Pe.
speech.line: T'is mo’t certaine.

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Looke to the Ladie, O ſhee's but ouer-joyde, Earlie in blustering morne this Ladie was throwne vpon this ſhore. I op't the coffin, found there rich Iewells, recoue-red her, and plac'ste her heere in Dianaes temple.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: May we ſee them?

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: Great Sir, they ſhalbe brought you to my house, whither I inuite you, looke Thaisa is recouered.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: O let me looke if hee be none of mine, my ſan-ctitie will to my ſense bende no licentious eare, but curbe it ſpight of ſeeing: O my Lord are you not Pericles? like him you ſpake, like him you are, did you not name a tem-pest, a birth, and death?

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: The voyce of dead Thaisa.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: That Thaisa am I, ſupposed dead and drownd.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I mortall Dian.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: Now I knowe you better, when wee with teares parted Pentapolis, the king my father gaue you ſuch a ring.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: This, this, no more, you gods, your present kinde-nes makes my past miseries ſports, you ſhall doe well that on the touching of her lips I may melt, and no more be ſeene, O come, be buried a ſecond time within these armes.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: My heart leaps to be gone into my mothers bo-some.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Looke who kneeles here, flesh of thy flesh Thaisa, thy burden at the Sea, and call’d Marina, for ſhe was yeel-ded there.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: Blest, and mine owne.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: Hayle Madame, and my Queene.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: I knowe you not.

speech.speaker: Hell.
speech.line: You haue heard mee ſay when I did flie from

speech.speaker: Tyre
speech.line: , I left behind an ancient ſubstitute, can you remem-ber what I call’d the man, I haue nam’d him oft.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: T'was Hellicanus then.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Still confirmation, imbrace him deere Thaisa, this is hee, now doe I long to heare how you were found? how poſſiblie preserued? and who to thanke (besides the gods) for this great miracle?

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: Lord Cerimon, my Lord, this man through whom the Gods haue ſhowne their power, that can from first to last resolue you.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Reuerent Syr, the gods can haue no mortall officer more like a god then you, will you deliuer how this dead Queene reliues?

speech.speaker: Cer.
speech.line: I will my Lord, beseech you first, goe with mee to my house, where ſhall be ſhowne you all was found with her. How ſhee came plac'ste heere in the Temple, no needfull thing omitted.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Pure Dian bleſſe thee for thy vision, and will offer night oblations to thee Thaisa, this Prince, the faire betro-thed of your daughter, ſhall marrie her at Pentapolis, and now this ornament makes mee looke dismall, will I clip to forme, and what this fourteene yeeres no razer touch't, to grace thy marridge-day, Ile beautifie.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: Lord Cerimon hath letters of good credit. Sir, my father's dead.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: Heauens make a Starre of him, yet there my Queene, wee'le celebrate their Nuptialls, and our ſelues will in that kingdome ſpend our following daies, our ſonne and daughter ſhall in Tyrus raigne. Lord Cerimon wee doe our longing ſtay, To heare the rest vntolde, Sir lead's the way.

speech.speaker: Gower.
speech.line: In Antiochus and his daughter you haue heard
Of monstrous lust, the due and iust reward:
In Pericles his Queene and Daughter ſeene,
Although aſſayl’de with Fortune fierce and keene.
Vertue preferd from fell destructions blast,
Lead on by heauen, and crown’d with ioy at last.
In Helycanus may you well descrie,
A figure of trueth, of faith, of loyaltie:
In reuerend Cerimon there well appeares,
The worth that learned charitie aye weares.
For wicked Cleon and his wife, when Fame
Had ſpred his cursed deede, the honor’d name
Of Pericles, to rage the Cittie turne,
That him and his they in his Pallace burne:
The gods for murder ſeemde ſo content,
To punish, although not done, but meant.
So on your Patience euermore attending,
New ioy wayte on you, heere our play has ending.
